abstract.p: Christopher Capozzola letter on Caleb Crain's May 21 review of An American Album: One Hundred and Fifty Years of Harper's Magazine notes Carey McWilliams condemned internment of Japanese-Americans in September 1942 Harper's article

block.p: In his review of ''An American Album: One Hundred and Fifty Years of Harper's Magazine'' (May 21), Caleb Crain describes as ''startling'' the ''promptness'' of Eugene V. Rostow's 1945 Harper's article condemning the internment of Japanese-Americans during World War II. Much more prompt was Carey McWilliams's September 1942 piece in the same magazine, in which he called the relocations ''a miracle of effective organization'' and suggested that ''in the long run the Japanese will probably profit by this painful and distressing experience.''
The wartime actions of a major national magazine are more ''startling'' than its feeble and tardy act of contrition.
